episode.title: Puyallup Tribe v. Department of Game of Washington

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: … and 319, The Puyallup Tribe, petitioner versus Department of Game of Washington, et. al., and Eugene Kautz, et. al. versus Department of Game of Washington.
Mr. Coniff, I believe you were arguing, you may continue your argument?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

Where we left off yesterday, I think I was discussing the impact of the off reservation Indian fisheries as they have developed in recent years upon the salmon and the steelhead resources of the State.

And in this connection, as you may recall, I was referring to certain graphs, which had been admitted into evidence by the trial court which I think demonstrate in graphical form the fundamental nature of the problem in terms of the salmon resource.
The graph which you presently see on the chart reflects --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Coniff, I wonder if before you get to that, if you can tell us just what rights under the fishing rights the Indians have under the Treaty as you see it?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: As I see it, Your Honor, the Indians have a right not to be discriminated against and by virtue of the language contained in the Treaty.

Now we are relying upon the phrase, “In common with the citizens of the territory” and as I mentioned to Your Honor, yesterday, this phrase “In common with the citizen of the territory” also appears in another context in the Yakima Treaty; that has to do with the right of the Indians to go upon the public road ways.
These are interpretations.

It's further supported, Your Honor, by the minutes of the Treaty itself, by the minutes of the Treaty of Medicine Creek and the minutes of the Treaty at Camp Walla-Walla, which led to the Treaty negotiated with the confederated tribes and bands that presently are on the Yakima Reservation.
This document was admitted into evidence at the trial court, plaintiff's Exhibit “45”.
It is a copy of the National Archives Minutes. Referring to page 7.

“It was also thought necessary to allow them to fish at all accustomed places since this could not interfere in any manner with the rights of citizens and was necessary for the Indians to obtain subsistence”.
This document I am referring, the certified copy of the minutes of the Treaty of Medicine Creek, which is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that in your Brief, the quote you just read us?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: No, it is not in my Brief, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do we have that document at all?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: This document is part of the record which was sent up and it is here.
This is the document I --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What page?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: This is at page 7, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Referring also to page 5 – may I have one moment – of the same document, “The great father has many white children who come here, some to build mills, some to make farms and some to fish and the great father wishes you to have homes, asked you for your horses and fishing places.
He wishes you to learn to farm and your children to go to a good school and he now wants me to make a bargain with you, etcetera”.
These are the only two references that do exist in the minutes of the Treaty Convention of Medicine Creek.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There is nothing about the commercial fishing on those notes?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I've read you the only two relevant portions that exist in this document.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I think we were told yesterday that in fact, the Indians did market some of their catch at that time?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that conceded?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: I will concede a very limited bartering although I will not -- at that time, the fish were extremely plentiful and it was certainly and it did not require any great deal of effort to obtain fish at that time, in aboriginal times or pre-treaty times by either Indian or non-Indian by simply putting in a very simple brush wear in shallow waters, which was the testimony at the trial court by the anthropologist.
The Indians were able to catch fish.
His testimony further was that the Indians did not fish in deep water.

They used spears, deep nets and brush wears in shallow water because they simply didn't have the technological ability at that time, with the materials that they had at that time, to construct an obstruction if you will to the deep water or the high velocity water streams; in other words, the main channels of the streams.
Their fishing activity occurred primarily in a more shallow tributaries in the various rivers that lead in or feed in into the Puget Sound area.
In this connection, I would like to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You said I think, y6ou concede that --

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: I concede unlimited barter.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- with the unlimited form of barter.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Unlimited barter and I believe the evidence in the records will substantiate that position but insofar as a large scale commercial enterprise, as we know it today, certainly, I will not concede that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In answer to the question, the basic question of the Chief Justice as to what your position is as to the meaning of this provision of the Treaty, I want to be sure you -- I understood your answer.
You said the -- you thought it simply guaranteed that the Indians would not be discriminated against?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That is correct.
Remembering, Your Honor, that at that time, the Indians at Puget Sound (Inaudible) 1855 were not citizens and could at that time be legally discriminated against.
And I think that if the Treaty is read or interpreted in light of its historical context or setting, I think that this gives credence to (Voice overlap) the interpretation that I'm reaching.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In other words, the Treaty gives them no more than the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment now gives the, and I realize that the Fourteenth Amendment was adopted after this Treaty?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, that is my contention, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any contention that you are administering this law against using the fish nets discriminatorily?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: There is no evidence in this record and in fact, this is simply not true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it being administered all over the State?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: It is being administered equally to Indians or applied to Indians as well as non-Indians.
In other words, the law is a, assuming it meets other constitutional test of reasonableness and legislative object and so forth, it is applied uniformly to persons regardless of race, creed or color.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What size is it -- any difference between nets of different sizes?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the distinction that has been legislatively drawn by the legislature of the State of Washington is that “Thou shall not place nets; thou shall not operate with operate gear or nets of the type and nature which had already been described in fresh water streams of the State” and as I mentioned yesterday, the reason for outlawing netting and fish wheels, fish traps, all are prohibited.
Dynamiting is prohibited. Poisoning of the river is prohibited by the legislature to protect these fish in their nurseries.
This fish must be able -- must be protected from a net fishery because it constitute such a hazard to the maintenance of the run.

As I've mentioned, Your Honor, the economic value of the fish is such that if we further would restrict the Puget Sound fishery for sport and commercial and we got more fish to the mouth of the river, we would merely see a greater Indian take.
And, I think this is demonstrated --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You really mean that if you've got 10 times as many fish at the mouth of the river get there now that there wouldn't be some feasible way of regulating the Indian fishing at the mouth of the river in order to ensure that enough fish got through and got up the river?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: My position is, Your Honor, that this is not feasible because, as I mentioned yesterday, I believe in response to Your Honor's question, the fish at the time that they make the transition from salt to fresh water, tend to mill and halt.
They actually go through a physiological change.

The salmon do in their upstream ascent to the spawning grounds and they will sometimes hold and the evidence on this record and the opinions of the experts that testified in the trial below, clearly indicate that this fish tend to mill and they will hold for three or four weeks.
They further, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but if you said -- I would suppose that if you said to the Indians who were fishing there that based on the number of fish that you find at the mouth of the river, if you said – your take should be limited to ex-fisher, ex pound and that's all.
Each day or some overall limit you could certainly find some way of guaranteeing that enough fish were left to get up the river.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You think that's just impractical?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: I must respectfully disagree with your statement.
I do believe there are sound biological or management reasons for this State law.
But further, Your Honor, I point out to you, is it alright to – and I don't mean to be facetious - but would it be permissible to rob a store if you only took $50 as opposed to $500.
The question that I see it from my client's point of view --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes but that assumes -- now you're going back to your first point that Indians don't have any right at all that -- and if the Court decides that the Indians do have some right beyond that the ordinary inhabitant, then he is not, he's not stealing $50 or a $1000.
He is exercising the right he is supposed to have?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: If the Court finds that he has this right then I think, as a matter of constitutional law, that the State has no right to regulate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At all?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Because the State would be then in the position ( Voice overlap) of defining the Treaty right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then this whole case turns upon whether there's a right or not?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It's either one way or another, it's either one way or all the other?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: As an alternative, I would offer to the Court the rationale utilized by the Court below, but that is not my primary contention.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let's assume though that there was this special right the Indians had another or shared by the other inhabitants.
You're suggesting to us that there's no practical way even if 10 times as many fisher arrived at the mouth of the river as were did it up stream.
There's no practical way of regulating Indian fishing so as to ensure that enough fish would go on up and still let the Indians catch some fish?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Are you assuming -- Oh!
May I?
I don't mean to ask you a question and respond to a question.
I would point out to you the problem of milling and holding.

I would further point out that if the question of how many fish is left to the Indians, I would seriously doubt that sufficient numbers would escape up the stream to the spawning grounds, to perpetuate the run in anyway, anywhere near the -- a production level as opposed to merely maintaining these species of fish in existence and by that I mean one or two fish.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I suppose you could do it theoretically get enough game wardens on night and day on every stream?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Are you assuming State regulation, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: It would be extremely difficult and force the problem.
In this connection, we do have a serious problem in the State of Washington with regards to the identification of members of these various 38 tribes.
To my knowledge, tribal rolls had been prepared for only the three or four largest tribes and the smaller tribes, the fragmented groups throughout Puget Sound, do not have membership rolls.
This has created serious problems in terms of law enforcement on the part of the game protector.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there no time of the year when it could be said that at that time, it is reasonable as a spawning season and that during that spawning season only the nets cannot be used rather than to say that that no time throughout the year could they fish there with such nets?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think that the time when anyone wants to fish is when the fish is there.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That that might be another thing but I'm speaking about biologically and scientifically, could they not limit it to the spawning season?
And after all, the only time you would really be interested in is the spawning season, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, in the opinion, to answer your question, Mr. Chief Justice, in the opinion of Dr. Van Cleave, the dean of the College of Fisheries, whose opinion was corroborated by Dr. Hamilton and Professor Donaldson, three eminently qualified biologists who have spent their life in science studying the problems of salmon.
In their opinion, the answer to your question would be no.
They give several reasons for it.
I've already mentioned two.

There are others. For example, if you have a net fishery which actually sweeps the spawning area itself, which of course are in these fresh water streams, even the fish that aren't taken tend to be disturbed, and tend to spawn unsuccessfully.
And there's data in the record which studies and observations which have been made by trained people to indicate that this is a side effect.
In other words, the fish are harassed at or about the time that they are to engage in the spawning act.
They will tend to spawn unsuccessfully.
In other words, they will spawn prematurely in deep water rather than going and making the nest or the red in the gravel in depositing the eggs and continuing on in that manner.
The --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: When does the steelhead season?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: When is the steelhead season?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I mean, when does the steelhead come in to spawn?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: In this particular river system, the steelhead --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: They're running right now, aren't they?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, they run December to March.
They are present in the river.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: The salmon come in, some come in in May?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: In the Puyallup system, they run through from approximately July to March, Your Honor.

At the various species are -- as adults here in the river, not all times in the river you will have the juveniles so that during their fresh water rearing period but we really not -- these nets do not affect the downstream or out stream migration of the juveniles, except insofar as the spawning nests are disturbed by people or nets being dragged across them.
They will tend to break up the nest and expose the eggs and they will then -- you will have extremely high mortalities at this particular --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You know when the jack salmon run?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm afraid -- in this river system, I --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: They run at various periods, don't they?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: They run at very various periods, is my recollection.
I just simply -- as I recall it, the definition of a jack salmon is that it's simply an immature salmon or salmon that came back a year too soon after spending his salt water type as a mature.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You should began in the big arguments.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: I'm aware of it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any limit put on the amount of fish that commercial fishermen can take in the Sound?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How is that regulated?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: It is regulated with regard to time, area and gear.

And I think in this connection, it could be pointed, it should be pointed out to the Court as an example that in the year 1942 on the Columbia River, they were allowed 274 days open for gill netting in the downstream or lower portions of the Columbia below Booneville Dam.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: By 274 days, how many could they catch during that time, all they could?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: All they could within the area that is open.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that fresh water?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That is fresh water, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, how did they do that?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: This is the only fresh water fishery for salmon, commercial fishery for salmon in the Pacific Northwest.
The reason --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I don't understand this, some of or part of your argument.
Statutes are set out in your Brief, aren't they on pages 8 and 9?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And the statute prohibits netting in the waters of the State.
That's a key phrase, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that means only fresh waters, is that right?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that -- and there must be some provision which I don't see it here which permits your Department of Fisheries to make exceptions to that, is that right?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I think --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So what's a Columbia River?
How did they permit commercial netting in the Columbia River?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: This is a 10% to the Columbia River compact, Your Honor, which is essentially joint management of the fishery by the States of Washington and Oregon.
This was ratified by Congress so that you have a concurrent jurisdiction established pursuant to the compact so that this particular (Voice overlap) will not apply.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright, now the State does permit commercial netting in salt water?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And I suppose the -- and you say that there's a limitation on that in terms of number of days which it might be done, is that right?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

The point I was making by my illustration was that there is -- there have been in the last 30 years greater and greater restrictions placed upon both commercial and sport fisheries, particularly commercial.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That might be fine but I suppose the Indians, one of the Indian statement is that they have a right to fish at customary places by the Medicine Creek Treaty and that then the State comes along and says, “You can't fish at all because can't -- net at all here in fresh water for conservation reasons” but at the same time, the State permits a commercial fisheries to net in the salt water.
Now, both of them result in the reduction of fish population.

And there are regulations and restrictions with respect to commercial fisheries and the question that we've been pursuing here as I understand it, is why can't there be a comparable commercial -- comparable regulations with respect to the Indians' use of nets.
Now, may be they can't be in terms of fish taken, but can't there be in terms of some reasonable arrangements with respect to days and what not?
The fish that the commercial fisheries catch, don't go back and spawn.

May be some of them are on their way back from having spawn but others, I suppose, are on their way to the river to spawn and that matter where the fish is apprehended if it doesn't get to it spawning place, it doesn't spawn, is that right?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But why -- is it your contention that this is evenhanded and that the Indians are not being regulated more drastically than the commercial fisheries?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: The Indians are being regulated, Your Honor, on the same basis as all other --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, that's what we're pursuing here because I'm not at all sure, Indians have a right to pursue their fishing at customary places.
Customary place here is at the mouth of the river and when you say you can't do it at the same time you permit the commercial fisheries to use nets and you subject them to regulation.
The question is -- are you taking your interpretation of the Treaty on that basis, are you really giving the Indians equivalent or equal treatment with the non-Indians?
That's a question and it is somewhat affected by practical consideration whether you could subject the Indians to comparable regulations – that is in terms of days or something like that.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: But, Your Honor, assuming, of course, that there is a special right that the Indians possessed by virtue of this Treaty language --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No, assuming your construction which is that this is a “right in common”, that is to say that they have a right to fish there, which is subject to regulation by the State, but that the regulation must -- within human exacted to you than no more, they even handed in its operation on the Indians on the one hand and on the non-Indians on the other?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: I would submit, Your Honor, that the record does not establish any discrimination on the part of the State of Washington with regard to entry or use of gear on the part -- because of bloodline ancestry.
In fact --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, if you had that kind of a public regulation about salmon, that you have about steelhead trout, I can understand that as I understand on steelhead trout, they can be taken only by hook and line by anybody.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: That's is correct.
It is last --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And here, what you say is that the Indians can't net.
Nobody can net in fresh water.
I mean, the Indians can't net at all per se if they don't have any particular status with respect to salt water and as practical matter they don't engage in that kind of commercial fishing.
But you say that the commercial fisheries can net out in salt water and it's arguable.
I'm not saying anything more than that but I'm suggesting to you that it's arguable; arguable that that is not the equality of treatment.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, I would have to respectfully disagree with you, Your Honor.
There are two points that do occur to me as a result of your statement.

The first is, that there in fact are numerous Indians who engage in the salt water fishery and in fact quite recently, the Bureau of Indians Affairs has obtained apparently the necessary appropriations and has purchased purse seine vessels for the Makah Tribes and the Makah Tribe is now going to be as a tribal operation, fishing commercial in the straits Juan de Fuca.
There are, as I mentioned, there are numerous Indians who do engage in the salt water fishery and there was certainly have no provisional limitation upon their ability to do so if they so desired.
I think another point that should be called to the attention of the Court has to do with the value of the fish at the time or at the point of its migration where it's caught.

Now if you take a fish that's up near the spawning grounds, you've got a fish that is changed substantially in quality, deteriorated in quality from that same bright fish, which would be taken in the salt water.
It has spent a great deal of its bodily energies in making its ascent or upstream migration.
Its flesh, it's body oils have been expanded.
It's flesh, rather than being firmed is soft and shrunky.
It is a very low commercial value fish.

The evidence, I believe, is in the record which indicates that some of this lower value fish would go down as low as three to five cents of pound for the first price to the fishermen as opposed to salt water in the same value of thirty-five to forty cents of pound.
These are very rough figures.
I'm giving you the exact market quotations but there is, there isn't can be and it is a substantial difference in the actual economic value of that fish, depending upon the point which it's taken.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why does the State limit commercial fishing to 280 odd days a year rather than 365?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Your Honor, I think this goes back about ten minutes and I know I'm going overtime in terms of my colleagues, I do want to point out that -- that was only the first part of my illustration.
In 1942, the States, under the Columbia River Compact, the States of Oregon and Washington allowed 274 days for gill nets in the Lower Columbia.
In 1967, the States of Washington and Oregon allowed 80 days, the same trend is apparent on the Puget Sound fishery, both as it would apply to purse seine or drift gill net type of fisheries.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So why did they put the 274 in the first place instead of 365?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: At that time, Your Honor, the management agencies, the persons who are trained in this field or in this science if you will, made the decision that they had a certain escapement goal to make.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They have what?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: An escapement goal to make of so many fish over Booneville Dam of the various species.
At that time, the runs were in a lot better shape than they are now.
So, therefore, they were able to meet their escapement goal and yet allow this much fishery.

In order to meet the same escapement goal for that same number of fish over Booneville Dam on the Columbia, they had to reduce the fishery on the various species in the Columbia on salmon now from 274 days in 1942 to 80 days in 1967 and those figures are not -- they are fairly reflective figures in terms of --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The reason I asked that question was if you can put an arbitrary date like that on the commercial fishing, why couldn't you put similar date on the gill nets at the mouth of the river?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I keep repeating myself but the problem is that if you allow a fishery there, it will say hypothesize one day a week and the fish that it's fishing, the stock that it's fishing is a stock that's milling as opposed to migrating, which is one reason by the way, Your Honors, that there is a fishery allowed in the lower Columbia for commercial purposes is because it is migration water as opposed to holding water.
This fish do not stop in their migrations.

They don't begin to stop until they are up either in the mouth of these rivers they've already made their salt to fresh transition in their life cycle and they don't begin to hold up until they begin to get up into the tributaries either above Booneville or up the water limit or one of the other tributaries in the Lower Columbia.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Can the commercial fishermen take them in the holding of waters?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: No, not in the Columbia nor anywhere in the State of Washington.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How do they fix out, by months or how?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: No, by area, by area prohibition and this is what this is (Voice overlap).

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- allow any fishing at all, any commercial --

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: There is no commercial fishing permitted in fresh water in the State of Washington, with the exception of the Lower Columbia, which is, as I mentioned, under this Columbia River Compact jointly managed by the two States.
I'm way overtime and I don't want to deprive my colleagues --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let me just ask you one question.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there any issue entered by the Indians based on the thesis of the government's argument that the Court should canvass and consider in order to determine whether the State laws were bad because they did not regulate the fishing better at the part of these waters that he says they should have regulated back.
Was that canvassed or considered by the Court?
Do we have any basis on which to reach a conclusion about those matters?
It seems to me like they somewhat complicate us.

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: It is a complicated thing, Your Honor.

It's something that we have – within the State of Washington and I'm sure in Oregon and Idaho also, we've delegated this management, responsibilities to persons who are trained in this area or in this field to act.
If they act arbitrarily or capriciously or don't do their jobs –-

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'd rather you'd leave out those words.

What I want to know is if there's anything in this record that would authorize us to reach a conclusion if we desire to do so; that the State laws are bad because they in some way discriminate and that they do not let enough fish come up into the place where the Indians fish.
Is there any mention in the record on which we can draw legitimate conclusions on that matter?

turn.speaker: joseph_lawrence_coniff_jr
turn.label: Mr. Joseph L. Coniff
turn.text: My answer would be no, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Johnston?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
If I can return a minute to what co-counsel was discussing, the fish are not frangible items.
They are not at all the same.
Even within a single stream, the fish are different.

They are possessed of different gene characteristics and they go to different parts of the stream and the difficulty with catching fish with a net at the mouth of the river on fresh water is that the fish mill around and they stay there and you fish over and over again on the same stocks.
The same fish are being fished today, tomorrow or next week, may be two weeks from now depending on how long they stay there.
And so what you would effectively do is you effectively destroy a certain portion of that run and that portion that once it's destroyed, it may never return again.
In other words, fish A may go three miles upstream, fish B will go four miles upstream, fish C will go five miles upstream.
If you remove fish A, there aren't anymore fish A's.
If you catch every fish A, then effectively you destroyed that portion of the run.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If you have commercial fishing for 274 days a year and some of those days, the fish are on their way through the Sound up to the rivers to spawn, you're cutting down the number too that are going up their to spawn, aren't you?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: You're always taking numbers.
That's the reason for having a resource; it's the utilizing.
And what you try to do -- if you're trying -- the commercial fishing as regulated in such a way -- the fishing boat stays in one place and the fish goes, the fish swim by essentially.

Now if the fishing boat stays in one place and the fish are staying in one place, everyday of scooping out the same sparks all the time and you're destroying, effectively destroying a portion of the run.
They will never, probably never, come back.
Commercial fishing is allowed in Puget Sound, for example --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They never come back if you catch them before they get there either, do they?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, that's right.
Now, a stream can only handle so many spawning fish in theory.
You can over spawn a stream.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So you give all that to the commercial fishermen?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, you don't give it to the commercial fishermen.
What you're trying to do is harvest it or take it. Let the commercial fishermen take it, that's right.
We're sports fishermen.
Take it.
And it makes no difference.
This bloodline ancestry is not of any concern to us.
The problem is where they catch the fish and how they catch the fish.
That's the important thing I think in this case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And there is also a question when they catch the fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: And when they catch the fish, that's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You agree with your colleague that there could be no season of the year when this could be done without serious damage to the spawn?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

I think the record, I think the testimony in this record of the most imminent biologists that we could find is in uniform and they all say that you cannot fish at the mouth of the river with nets and the reason is that you're fishing the same fish over and over and over again.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Has the State ever attempted to make any contract or agreement with the Indians here and get federal action so as to supersede the Treaty or substitute an amendment of the Treaty that provide some substitute right for the Indians here, whether or not strictly the -- whatever may be the strict construction of the Treaty?

Because if you start of with the conclusion, I'm not saying that I do but that's what this litigation is about fundamentally, you start off with the conclusions that the Indians have a right here and that that right is being impaired by the regulation.
The fact that the regulation may be highly desirable and I think you made what sounds to me at the moment like a noble almond (ph) case to that effect, but that that kind of irrelevant consideration.
Probably, you start off with the conclusion that the Treaty does confer a right on the Indians and the State is totally depriving the Indians of that right totally, then it's a very difficult case.
But was there some reference to another situation which the States have provided the Indians with gear and boats so that they could engage in salt water fishing?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Counsel was referring, Your Honor, to a program that's run by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, the Department of Interior where they either subsidize or make outright grants of monies to Indians so that they may engage in commercial fishery, a legal salt water fishery.
In other words, they -- long term loans for boats and equipment, a low interest loans so the Indians may (Voice overlap).

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's not by way of modification of the Treaty?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I don't know whether these Treaties can be modified or superseded by appropriate action on the part of the Tribe and the federal government.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, the Treaty, Your Honor, can be changed by an act of Congress tomorrow.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's right.
Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's without consent from no one.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Has that been attempted?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: It's a very difficult thing to pass Indian legislation in Congress, Your Honor.
It's extremely difficult.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I know, but had there been any effort to obtain an amendment so far as this Treaty is concerned?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: In the 1963, Your Honor, I think Senator Magnuson introduced to two different resolutions in the Senate: one saying that the Indian Treaty right was no more and no less than an a right to be equal; and the other said that the United States should purchase the Indian's Treaty right whatever it was.
Hearings were held before the Senate Interior Committee and that was into the matter.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That was referred to in the Briefs?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, they are not, Your Honor.
I do not believe so.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is it your position that the State of Washington has no obligation to -- in the event that it breeches the Treaty to these Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I say, is it your position that the State of Washington has no obligations to the Indians whatsoever in the event that it, the State breeches the Treaty?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: You mean, would we be liable on damages?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I said “Any right” that you -- any obligation.
I don't say it's a question of damages but you have any obligation to preserve the rights of the Indians under that Treaty.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, we have an obligation, I would assume there were law of the land, Your Honor and if the Treaty right is such that the Indians do have the right to fish, we will certainly respect that and we won't attempt to regulate.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is your position here on the -- as far as that Treaty is concerned, that the Indians have no rights under that Treaty at the present time; that the State could make any regulations that it wants in the interest of conservation, and not withstanding the Treaty?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
That's our position: that the Treaty gave the right to the Indians.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, isn't much of what were talking about extraneous if that issue your position?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And if there is any -- there are any rights that they have a right to protect as against the State of Washington and you lose, don't you?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, we lose.
Our position essentially is that the Treaty gave the Indians a right to fish in common with the citizens of the territory.
In 1855, the Indians had effectively had no right.
As a legal matter, they had no right.
There weren't citizens.
They were just simply people who had been defeated and conquered.
The Treaty was made with them and they gave them a right to fish in common.
It was a grant from the United States to the Indians, not the other way around.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now suppose the State of Washington should decides that it also interfered with spawning, and if there was any fishing at all on these rivers that go through the Indian reservation, could they say that no one could fish there and then justified on the ground that they're dealing with the Indians same as the other, the public?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Not on reservations, Your Honor.
I think reservations have a completely different legal status.
We make no claim whatever to regulate Indian fishing on Indian reservations.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They use gill nets there?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, as a matter of fact, they do in the State of Washington.
Yes, sir, quite extensive like –

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You don't have to regulate that?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: We do not make any attempt to regulate.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I gathered from someone yesterday that it was not the entire tribe can be doing this fishing, certain individuals, is that right?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does Tribe get anything out of it?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Ordinarily, Your Honor, being completely candid, I would say no.
It's usually –

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you have -- do you have a personal private contract made by several Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, I am not so sure it's quite a contract, Your Honor.
I think in the case of the Puyallup River for example, it's more the law of the sword.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: More what?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: More the law of the sword, the strongest Indians get the best fishing places and the weaker Indians --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, how did the entire Tribe have to be a part of this lawsuit?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: We joined them as defendants, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Because the right to fish, if there is such a right, is a tribal right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But this right is being exercised by Individuals?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: By individuals, that's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not by the tribe?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have they conveyed their rights to these Indians, these two or three Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, it's a communal right, Your Honor.
It's a communal right, but it can only be exercised by people acting individually.
Somebody has to go and put the net in the river and each Indian --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What you have, as I understand it, is a mere commercial fishing that people [Inaudible] of it, two or three or four Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

I think at the time of the trial in this case, we kind of involved all the Indians in the State of Washington who were fishing in what we consider to be an illegal manner and they were only, I think approximately a 174 Indians in the whole State of Washington, there are fishing what we consider to be illegal.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And how did the others fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, if they fish in a general commercial fishery, we don't even know that they're Indians.
In other words --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where they do fish, but it's not commercial.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What means do they use?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Any lawful means.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what law?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, a net if they're fishing commercially in the Puget Sound, a hook and line if they are fishing for sport.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course on the reservation, they might use means which off the reservation would be illegal.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.
They used nets on reservations that when they come outside the reservation and use those means and that's when we get in the situation that we are presently in.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would there be any difference in your position if the Tribe was doing this gill net fishing as a communal matter instead of individuals as we have here?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do these individuals have any right under the Treaty, different to that which is the right of the tribe from mixed up about to suing the tribe?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Well, we brought the suit against the tribe because we wanted to get the whole issue settled.

If we have sued a single individual, they may well have argued that we fail to join in an indispensable party because the right flows from the United States through the Treaty to the Tribe as an entity, but it's exercised by the Individual.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The tribal right may be exercised by any members of the Tribe?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And if he does exercise it, what he gets he keeps for himself.
He doesn't have to share with other members?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does one number of the Tribe has the right to go catch all the fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: I would say if he can, yes, Your Honor.
If he is physically capable of doing that.
Now, some Tribes cooperate a little better with each other than others.
It would be less unfair if I didn't say that but when speak in terms of a Tribe, it's not a monolithic entity in the State.
It's a very loosely organized and loosely defined situation.
For example, we don't know who an Indian is.
We talked on that some yesterday.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is this case in anyway fight between the several commercial Indians and the fishing [Inaudible] and other commercial fishers in general?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, sir, and it's not.
It's a fight merely bet -- as we look at it, as we view it, it's a fight merely between the fish and someone who would tend to destroy the runs.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Just tell me what's the record had a lot about this commercial operations by the three Indians, are they related or something?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How large in operation is that?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Before it was enjoined -- in Washington you have a fish ticket system.
When you sale a fish commercially, the buyer makes out of ticket.
He sends a copy, one copy of that to the State and that it has the poundage and the price paid per pound.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does that work pretty well?
You think you get accurate reports?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, as long as it's legal fishery.
In 1963, the gross receipts that we received from the State were a $124,000.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When there was a very large operation, I asked --

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it was a large operation.
They had as much gear in the river as physically the river could accommodate.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, does it compare in proceeds with what the commercial fishermen in the area that set aside for the salt water?
Would they get in the way of proceeds?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: I would say it was a fairly large operation, yes, Your Honor.
I would say it was a large commercial fishing operation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And is this just three?
Were they --

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: There were three brothers and they would have people working for them of and on tbut --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And those three brothers are members of this particular Tribe, was it?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, sir, members of the Puyallup Tribe, that's correct, that's our standing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Didn't someone say yesterday that there were about nine million salmon caught up there in a season and that about eighty thousand of them were caught by the Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: I think that the numbers used yesterday were nine million fish and 818,000 fish caught by the Indians.
I think that, and perhaps I'm not correct that it was pounds instead of numbers of fish - Nine million pounds of fish.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything in this record from which we can read decisions that law is being operated in such a way that [Inaudible] fishing with nets that large commercial companies on the outside who are able to fish otherwise than which is being given an unfair advantage over the Indians?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, Your Honor, there is not.
There's absolutely nothing in this record.
This is not an equal case.
There's nothing -- there's not one; not a shred of evidence in the case on that.
It matters not who does the fishing; it's where, when and how.
We cannot as to who.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: These three Indian brothers get at fish while the others are fishing?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: They certainly can.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It would have been a law to prevent it?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the place where the stream that if they catch too many of them before they go up to the mouth of the river, isn't it?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That there was alluded to yesterday, Justice Black, by a counsel for the United States.
But what we really should do is cut down the fishing in the Sound and let more fish get to the mouth of the River.
Well, it sounds nice but it simply doesn't work that way.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there been any issue of that kind canvassed to any extent whatever?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
It's simply a statement.
It appears in their Brief and it appeared yesterday in oral argument and it simply a statement that first plus sounds logical, but it's not biologically sound.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, is it biologically sound to -- would it be biologically sound to set some for the State to fix such certain number of days during which time the Indians may fish?
They use nets in fresh water?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, it's not biologically sound to use nets in fresh water by anybody --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: At any time?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: At any time, that's correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I suppose cause -- upsets the fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: It's not somewhat, sir.
That does in fact happen but and that also, the fishing in over and over on the same spawning stock and you remove various portions of gene pools.

What you're trying to do is take the random sample out of the whole run as it passes a certain point and when the run gets to the river and the fish stop, and then you keep fishing over and over again on these same fish, that's when you get into your extreme difficulty even if you can regulate the numbers that they take or the pounds that they take.
You destroy the individual gene sources and the run is destroyed ultimately.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So even if you said you're going to limit the Indian fishing to 'X' pound, that 'X' pound may just happen to include too many fish of a certain kind?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's no way of avoiding that?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: The only way to avoid it would be to fish out where everyone else fishes.
In other words, fishing transportation what we call “transportation water”.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where the fish are moving?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Where the fish are moving, that's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask it, does that $128,000 proceed, does that reflect the price for fish something as we were told earlier?
Depending on where you catch them, you may get only three to five cents pound that you catch some other places you may get $35 cents of pound?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And does this reflect sales of the lower price?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, it reflects else of a quality fish.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Quality fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Quality fish, that's correct, right at the mouth of the river.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If these Indians were denied their right to fish at the mouth of the river with nets, what other way of fishing is open to them that would be practical?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: They can take their nets and fish in a salt like everyone else.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They could take their nets and go at the salt water?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what about fishing at the mouth of the stream?
How could they fish there?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: The only way that they can fish there is with the hook and line and a fishing pole.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Like everybody else?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Like everybody else.
And --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they take -- they take their nets out to the salt water means you have to have --

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And I gather this Tribe is not one of those as yet.
I think the Tribe has been getting the subsidy that you mentioned and given the equipment, the boats and such, is not this Tribe, isn't it?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.
These two Tribes that were dealing with are the Nisqually and the Puyallups.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Which is the Tribe that has a subsidy?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: The Makah Indians and there may will be others too, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are they some distance from where we are?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: They are in the northwestern tip of the State of Washington.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now what about the other members of the Tribe who share this right, are they making any effort to fish?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: I think it depends on the tenacity of individual, frankly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you objecting only a -- is this commercial fishery just at the mouth of the river or is it also up river?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Depending on the river, it goes up the river as far as it's feasible for the Indians to catch fish.
In other words, they will catch them in any place they can.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And how far up the river do they put up nets?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: In terms of miles under particular stream?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, it's not just at the mouth?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, in the case of the Puyallups, it went up to the time somewhere, which I would guess is about ten miles.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it's fish that whole run down?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And all through this water, fish just sometimes just milling?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
And, of course, the primary place to fish is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is at the mouth?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: -- is at the mouth.
That's the best place because get the first crack of the resource.
Everybody behind you has to take what's over from your operation are the fish that escaped your nets.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did I understand that the salmon run in the Sound has decreased remarkably in the last few years?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Over the long haul, Your Honor, that's correct.
In the Puget Sound (Voice overlap).
Pardon?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To what extent has it decreased?
Well, if you know --

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, I do not know precisely, Your Honor, in terms of fishing days or in terms of how it's taken but the resource is dwindling and the reason that it's dwindling is because the environment has slowly but surely being destroyed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So really, though this isn't the interest of the commercial fishery, doesn't it to stop the Indians from fishing at round the river within fish to run for your commercial fishing?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Oh!
It's in the interest of maintaining the resource and it's commercial fishermen benefit from that and that's correct.
But it's not -- it's in the Indians own interest themselves.
The Hoko River is a perfect example of what happens when you over fish a stream.
In 1952, they got 10,000 silver salmon in the Hoko River.
It's a stream that runs through the reservation and we have no control over it and then the runs have gone down to about 3,000 fish a year, that's their take.
That resource has effectively been destroyed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that necessarily from the Indian fishing or might be from 274 days a year commercial fishing?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: No, sir.
Well, there's not 274 days of commercial fishing left anymore.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I know, but why then did they drop the 274 to 80?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Because the resource is dwindling.
The total numbers of fish available are coming down.
They're getting smaller.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did you have the same thing in the Sound which you have here?
Your fish is dwindling because of the method of fishing and the number of fish they take.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Your Honor, the reason that the runs are – they are going down over a long period of time.
It's the difference between 274 days and 80 days was 27 years.
In other words, the fishing time was cut down over a period 27 years.
Here's another example of what happens.
This is the Yakima River.
It's a river that runs through an Indian reservation.
The Indians have a perfect legal right to fish there as much as they like in any matter and in any means they'd care to choose.
In 1953, there are approximately a catch of about 2,000 salmon and that was in the escapement and the escapement to spawn of about 6,000 salmon.
The catch goes up and the spawning -- the numbers of fish available for spawning have to decrease.
It simply have to decrease because there are only so many fish in the river.
The more you catch, the fewer there are to spawn.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understand that the only legal [Inaudible] is that we have a long commercial fishing season.
They're bound to catch fish along their way up to spawn.

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If you stop them, if you don't stop them from taking those fish when they are their way up to spawn, why don't you contribute very greatly to the same condition that you say will exist if the Indians are permitted to gill net on the river?

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Your Honor, these fish are already in the river.
They're there and that's where did they take it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I know, I know those --

turn.speaker: mike_r_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Mike R. Johnston
turn.text: Alright, and it does no good.
It does no good to let 400 fish get to the river, if the Indians are going to take all 400 of them.
It makes no difference whether it's 400 or a 1000.

They're going to take them all if you -- ordinarily, with that 500 fish get to the river and you let a 1000 get to the river and the Indians take all a 1000, it makes no difference to the spawning, that's just as barren and just as empty.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Woodworth?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I speak of the interest of Oregon in this litigation because Oregon shares with Washington a community of interest, which is particularly referred to the area of the Columbia River drainage.

The Columbia River runs between Oregon and Washington and by virtue of congressional approval of a compact between the States, Oregon and Washington jointly managed the Columbia River, fishing on the Columbia River.
Now, the Columbia River is different from the Puyallup River or the rivers in most of western Washington because the Columbia River is the highway by which the fish reach the up river streams.
So we have a little different problem in the Columbia River that is indicated in the rivers of western Washington.
In that river, there have been built a great number of dams.
It started in 1941 with the completion of Grand Coulee Dam.
Grand Coulee Dam wiped out 1100 miles of salmon spawning streams.

Since that time there have been five dams built below Coulee, each of which has had its impact on the -- not only on the ability of the fish to spawn, but on the ability of the fish to reach their spawning beds.

And it's for this reason because that -- the States of Oregon and Washington have used their staffs of experts in the fisheries to attempt to determine how many fish must pass up the river in order to preserve the runs.
I think it's been spoken up here that in 1911, 50 million pounds of fish were harvested out of the Columbia River.
That was in 1911.
Since and the last figure we have was for 1967 when 9 million pounds were harvested and 1967 was one of the best years we've had in the Columbia River in recent years.
In -- part of this period, when we've kept records, we've kept the record of the Indian catch because they report it to the selling agencies.
In 1959, the Indians on the Columbia River caught 39 thousand pounds of salmon.
In 1967, when we think there were probably not more than 75 or may be 80 Indians fishing, they caught 1,300,000 pounds of fish.
The whole purpose of the two agency's activities on the Columbia River has been to enable enough fish to get upstream, to keep an even balance if we could just keep --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, is any difference between the effect of the Indian catch and the non-Indian catch on the Columbia River?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: The non-Indian catch has been materially reduced.
It's been reduced --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, but what difference is it though in the biological cycle of the salmon whether it's caught by Indian or non-Indian?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: None, Mr. Justice Fortas.
They --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, what's the point you're making?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: The point I make is that conservation and regulation of fishing is necessary and the Indians ought to be included in that regulation because it's a matter of concern for all of the people of the community; that enough fish be permitted to reach the spawning ground.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, are you -- on the Columbia River are they not regulated?
Are they doing something that non-Indians can't do?
Or is this – or is your point just that Indians are catching more fish?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: Indians are catching more fish because the State of Oregon has been enjoined by the federal court from interfering with the Indian fishing.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, are they doing something that non-Indians can't do, cannot do?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
They were fishing in an area, part of their fishing was in an area close to non-Indian fishing.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now how much of that million odd pounds is counted for by that?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: I would say that -- no, I wouldn't try to answer.
I'd had to guess, Your Honor, but in terms of fishing stations --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Because if I understand it, this case is not being presented anyway on the theory that Indians ought to catch less and non-Indian commercial fisheries ought to catch more.
I mean to say that that's proposition one why it's kind of a remote.
And the issues here and the question is whether in areas where Indians are claiming Treaty rights, they are properly claiming Treaty rights to which they are entitled (Voice overlap).

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: I agree with the Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- whether the fish had been caught by Indians on one hand and non-Indians on the other hand, both of them being subjected to the same regulation?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: I think it's the position of the State of Oregon, Your Honor, that the Indian fishery should be subject to some modicum of regulation in those areas where the fish are most vulnerable.
As Mr. Coniff and Mr. Johnston have pointed out, when the fish reach the streams in which they propagate, they're most vulnerable.
They can --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But I want to be sure that Oregon would also -- you're saying that Oregon would also apply that same regulation to non-Indians.
Are you saying that or not?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: Oregon tried to make an arrangement with the Indians a few years ago and had an arrangement that worked for several years.
However, in the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Why didn't you talk about the warm --

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: Warm springs in the Yakimas, Mr. Justice Douglas, and the Umitillas and to an extent The Nez Perce participated in it, although they went -- and this was not a separate Treaty.
This was worked out through the biologists of our State and the interested people in the Indian groups.
Then, a few years ago, as the fishing became harder, some of the Indian groups, with group from the organization, the Warm Springs pattern their fishing programs after State regulation.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You talked about fishing on the reservations or off?

turn.speaker: george_s_woodworth
turn.label: Mr. George S. Woodworth
turn.text: No.
